title-group.article-title: Tibialis Anterior Tendon Entrapment After Ankle Tightrope Insertion for Acute Syndesmosis Injury

author-notes.corresp: Matthew James Welck, MBChB, BSc (Hons), MRCS, SpR Trauma & Orthopaedics, Barnet Hospital, The Beeches, 4 Newlands Avenue, Radlett, Herts WD78EL, UK; e-mail: matthewwelck@doctors.org.uk.

abstract.p: Ankle syndesmotic injuries often require anatomic reduction and fixation. Syndesmosis screw fixation is commonly used; however, this prevents physiological motion at the joint, often requires a second operation for screw removal, and may limit postoperative weight bearing. The Ankle Tightrope (Arthrex, Naples, FL) was introduced to allow physiological tibiofibular micromotion, early ankle range of motion, and weight bearing, and did not require a second operation for removal. For Maisonneuve injuries, or more severe syndesmosis instability, a second tightrope is required. This is advised to be placed 1 cm above the first with axial divergence in the coronal plane to increase rotational stability. Initial series have shown the main complications of tightrope fixation to be knot prominence or wound complications. Other documented complications include erosion of the buttons into bone, synostosis, and diastasis. This is the first report of tendon entrapment from the medial button. Reasons for this are discussed with suggestions for surgical technique.
Levels of Evidence: Therapeutic, Level IV

disp-quote.p: “Injury to the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis generally involves external rotation of the foot, eversion of the talus, and/or hyperdorsiflexion force.”

body.p: The tibia and fibula are connected distally by the syndesmosis to provide a tight and dynamic mortise for the talar dome. The syndesmosis is composed of 5 ligaments, which help regulate the distal tibiofibular joint such that through full ankle plantar to dorsiflexion, the intermalleolar distance increases by approximately 1.5 mm. In plantar flexion, the fibula migrates distally and translates medially, whereas in dorsiflexion it migrates proximally, translates laterally, and externally rotates 2° to 5° to accommodate the widened anterior part of the talus.1

The ligaments of the syndesmosis include the anterior inferior tibiofibular ligament (AITFL), the posterior inferior tibiofibular ligament (PITFL), the interosseous ligament (IOL), the transverse tibiofibular ligament (TTFL), and the posterior intermalleolar ligament (PIML). The AITFL, PITFL, and IOL hold the fibula and tibia together. The IOL represents the thickened distal portion of the interosseous membrane.2 Although the weight-bearing area of the talus does not contact the fibula, 6% to 15% of body weight is transmitted to the fibula via these strong ligaments.1 The TTFL is located in a deep part of the PITFL and forms part of the articular surface for the talus and helps prevent posterior talar translation. The role of the PIML remains largely unknown.1

Injury to the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis generally involves external rotation of the foot, eversion of the talus, and/or hyperdorsiflexion force.3 This is usually accompanied by rotational ankle fractures, such as the pronation external rotation and supination external rotation injury, according to the classification by Lauge-Hansen.4 Syndesmosis instability must be considered with fibula fractures above the level of the syndesmotic ligaments. This includes a Maisonneuve injury with high fibular fracture. Yamaguchi et al reported that syndesmotic fixation was only necessary if the fibular fracture was greater than 4.5 cm proximal to the tibial plafond in the presence of medial disruption.5 Injury to the syndesmosis without fracture has been reported.6

Xenos et al demonstrated in a cadaveric study that section of the AITFL caused a 2.3 mm diastasis of the distal tibiofibular joint. When the distal 8 cm of the IOL was also sectioned, this increased to 4.5 mm, and when the TTFL and PITFL were also sectioned, the total diastasis was 7.3 mm.7 The medial structures also play a key role in preventing ankle diastasis.8 This diastasis results in increased tibiotalar shear stresses, altered contact patterns, and talar shift, which accelerate osteoarthritis. As little as 1 mm of talar shift results in a 40% loss of tibiotalar contact surface area.9 It is therefore essential that the syndesmosis is anatomically reduced.

In general, syndesmosis injuries can be treated with conservative interventions if no severe tear to the ligaments are present and if no bone fracture is present. However, with more severe injuries, surgical stabilization is generally required for anatomic reduction of the syndesmosis and to restore stability to the ankle mortise.10 The need for syndesmosis stabilization should be assessed clinically and radiographically in the operating theatre. A common method is to grasp the distal fibula with a pointed reduction clamp, after fixation of the malleoli, and to pull laterally under direct fluoroscopic evaluation.10 Another way is to apply a dorsiflexion and external rotation force to the foot, while watching the syndesmosis under the fluoroscope.
Syndesmosis screw fixation is commonly used for acute injury; however, there is controversy regarding the position and size of the screw, the number of cortices, and the number of screws.1,10

Problems associated with syndesmosis screw fixation include excessive rigidity preventing physiological motion at the joint, malreduction, screw loosening and breakage, the debated need for a second operation for screw removal, and a prolonged period of postoperative reduced weight bearing.11-13

With the concept that the ideal syndesmosis repair implant should be strong enough to prevent diastasis, but allow physiological micromotion, early ankle range of motion, and weight bearing, and not require a second operation for removal, alternative techniques for syndesmosis fixation have been introduced.

These include bioabsorbable screws and suture endobuttons (such as The Ankle Tightrope; Arthrex, Inc, Naples, FL).14 The latter concept has the strength to resist diastasis, yet still allows physiological micromotion of the joint and does not require removal.

The Tightrope has a preassembled loop of No. 5 Fiberwire suture material, tensioned between 2 terminal metallic end buttons. The Fiberwire consists of para-aramid synthetic fiber, Kevlar, coated with polyester. It is therefore resistant to stretch.15

A 4-mm drill hole is made through both cortices of fibula and tibia, 1.5 cm above the tibial plafond in the transmalleolar plane. The fiberwire with the leading medial button are then passed through the hole from the lateral side, on a needle with pull through suture and exits the medial skin.

The angle of traction on the pull through suture is then changed to flip the medial button against the medial tibial cortex. The pull through suture is then cut and removed. The lateral end button is then tightened down on the lateral side by pulling the lateral free ends of the syndesmosis suture with the fibula in the reduced position. The fiberwire is then cut 1 cm from the end to allow the knot to lay down and prevent knot prominence.15,16 It is advised that the Tightrope is tightened with the ankle internally rotated and plantar flexed. A second tightrope is advised to treat Maisonneuve injuries, or if further syndesmosis stability is required. This additional tightrope aims to provide enhanced rotational stability. The second should be placed 1cm above the first, with a similar fibular entry point, but axial divergence to increase rotational stability (see Figure 1).

caption.p: The suggested configuration for double tightrope fixation. The second should be 1 cm proximal to the first.

body.p: Postoperatively, it is recommended the patient does not bear weight for 2 weeks, then allowed to bear partial weight for the subsequent 4 weeks.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: Mrs JS is a 49-year-old lady who is medically fit and well. She sustained a left Weber B, bimalleolar ankle fracture in May 2010. This was internally fixed with 2 partially threaded screws for the medial malleolus and a tubular plate for the fibular fracture.

She sustained a further fall in December 2011, when she presented to our department. Radiographs demonstrated a refracture of the medial malleolus with some bending of the screws and a proximal fibula fracture. There was also distal tibiofibular diastasis (see Figure 2).

caption.p: Post reinjury radiographs showing the refracture of the medial malleolus with screw bending and a tibiofibular diastasis.

sec.p: This was treated with double tightrope fixation. One screw from the plate was removed to place one tightrope, and the second was inserted 1 cm distal to the first, with a more posterior fibular entry point (at the posterior edge of the plate), in order to obtain axial divergence (see Figure 3).

caption.p: Initial postoperative films. Showing one tightrope through the plate, angled posteriorly, and the second posterior to the plate, angled anteriorly.

sec.p: In the immediate postoperative period, the patient was suffering with severe anterior ankle pain. This was exacerbated by ankle dorsiflexion and plantar flexion.She also described a sharp pain on the dorsomedial aspect of the foot. There was paraesthesia in the distribution of the deep peroneal nerve.

The patient was taken back to the operating theatre, and on exploration of the distal, medial button, it was found to be entrapping the tibialis anterior muscle and in close proximity to the deep peroneal nerve. The offending tightrope was removed, a further screw was removed, and the second tightrope put through the plate (see Figure 4).

caption.p: After refixation. The second tightrope can now be shown to also be through the plate.

sec.p: She went on to make an uneventful recovery and was back to her prefracture mobility after 6 weeks. The paraesthesia completely resolved.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The early results for the ankle tightrope have been promising. Thornes et al demonstrated suture with endobutton fixation to be as effective and significantly more reliable than a single 4-cortical 4.5-mm syndesmosis screw.17

Thornes et al also compared suture endobutton to screw fixation and reported the patients in the suture group all maintained their reduction, had significantly better American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) scores at 3 and 12 months, and returned to work sooner. In addition, 12 of 16 patients in the screw group required removal, compared with zero in the suture endobutton group.18
Coetzee et al reported a significantly improved AOFAS score (94 vs 88) for those randomized to fixation with tightrope compared to screw fixation.11

Qamar et al15 and Mcmurray et al19 reported the use of the ankle Tightrope in small cohorts of patients and concluded that it is a dependable and safe alternative to screw fixation, with possibility for accelerated rehabilitation.

In the largest series to date of 49 patients, mean time to full weight bearing was 7.7 ± 1.1 weeks, and the mean duration to return to normal activities was 11.2 ± 1.8 weeks. A total of 85.7% reported their outcome as excellent or good and 12% as good.11
Although the suture-endobutton construct addresses many of the problems associated with screw fixation, there are still some areas of concern.

In the literature to date, the majority of the documented complications arise from knot prominence or wound complications. Other documented complications include erosion of the buttons into the bone, synostosis, and diastasis. This is the first documented report of tendon entrapment from the medial button.

Forsythe et al showed a significant increase in diastasis during external rotation stress in cadaver specimens with sectioned syndesmoses stabilized with a tightrope, compared with a 4-cortical 4.5-mm cortical screw.20 However, in the clinical scenario, external rotation is avoided for 6 weeks to allow some ligamentous healing. Moreover, it may be advantageous to have a less rigid fixation. Klitzman et al found the suture-endobutton construct to be more similar to the native syndesmosis than screw fixation in cadavers. The screw fixation was found to be significantly more rigid.21

With higher fibula fractures (Weber C),tightrope fixation alone is likely not enough to prevent proximal migration of the distal fibula fragment, and therefore should be supplemented with fibula fracture osteosynthesis.12
Qamar et al reported 2 out of 16 (12.5 %) superficial wound infections; 1 (6.25%) had tightrope removal due to knot irritation.15

Treon et al reported 19 patients over 3 years, with 22% tightropes removed due to wound breakdown or knot prominence. Eleven percent developed syndesmosis widening, 5.5% synostosis, and 5.5% knot prominence without removal, and therefore reported a cumulative complication rate of 44%.22
Willmott et al reported soft tissue irritation with foreign body granuloma formation, necessitating implant removal in 2 out of 6 patients.23

Gadd et al reported the outcomes in 38 patients treated with a tightrope. Thirty had a good functional outcome; however, 2 patients required tightrope removal and significant would debridement following tibial and fibular osteomyelitis.24

Degroot et al reported 24 patients and found it to be an effective method to repair the syndesmosis. However, 6 patients required removal of the suture endobutton device due to local irritation. Four patients developed osteolysis of the bone and subsidence of the device into the bone, and 3 patients developed heterotopic ossification within the syndesmotic ligament.25

This report is the first to document tendon entrapment secondary to ankle tightrope fixation. This was mainly due to the fact the surgeon had attempted to alter the angle of the second tightrope in the coronal plane.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: As with any device, there is always a learning curve to successful use. The suture-endobutton technique addresses many of the deficiencies with syndesmotic screw fixation. The predominant complication encountered so far are the frequent knot and wound complications; Naqvi et al13 proposed a modification to the technique whereby the periosteum over the posterior surface of the fibula was elevated using sharp dissection, to create a recess to bury the knot. They found that 0 of 31 patients had wound complications using this technique, whereas 3 of 18 prior to the modification did.

With this experience, we advise that care is taken when trying to obtain axial divergence of the second tightrope for increased rotational stability, as is recommended by the manufacturer. If a screw is located in the fibular plate at the level of the second tightrope, necessitating the fibular entry point to be anterior or posterior to the plate, the surgeon must be extremely mindful of angulation when drilling.
